definition:
Given a random variable $X$, the *moment generating function* of $X$ is
the following function:\

$M_X(t) = E[e^{tX}]$ for $t \in R$ (if the expectation converges).

It can be shown that if the moment generating function of $X$ is defined
on an interval around the origin, then\

$E[X^k] = M_X^{(k)}(t) |_{t=0} $\

In other words, the $k$th-derivative of the moment generating function
evaluated at zero is the $k$th moment of $X$.
